awd_titl_txt: SusChEM: Collaborative Research: Role of Biofilms in Engineered Infiltration Systems in the Removal of Bacteria in Urban Stormwater
awd_abstract_narration:
1511915(Chen) & 1511941(Li)

Urbanization has resulted in a significant increase in surfaces which prevent stormwater from infiltrating the subsurface and recharging the groundwater. Instead, stormwater accumulates as surface runoff that can result in streambed erosion and flooding events. The runoff can also pick up contaminants (e.g., pathogens) from the surfaces, which eventually enter and contaminate natural aquatic systems. An important component of this research is to investigate the influence of variation in stormwater chemistry and length of drying periods on the chemical properties and microbial diversity of the biofilms and the efficiency of biofilm-modified engineered infiltration systems to remove bacteria during a storm event.

This research is the first to systematically study the effects of biofilms grown under environmentally relevant conditions in engineered infiltration systems on the removal of bacteria from stormwater. The changes in the structure, distribution, and microbial diversity of biofilms in porous media grown under a variety of environmental conditions will be revealed for the first time through confocal laser scanning microscopy and high throughput sequencing. The use of atomic force microscopy for the measurements of interfacial forces between a bacterial colloid probe and biofilms will shed light on how a variety of biofilm structures will influence the interfacial interactions between bacteria and biofilm-modified surfaces and the propensity for bacteria to adhere to biofilms. By coupling pore scale and continuous scale modeling, this work will quantitatively link the influence of biofilms on pore scale hydrodynamics with the rate of bacteria transport and attachment at continuum scale. This research will provide new insights on the mechanisms for bacterial retention during filtration, as well as the remobilization of bacteria during draining in biofilm-modified engineered infiltration systems. This research is transformative because it reveals the intricate relationship between environmental conditions, physicochemical properties and microbial diversity of biofilms, and bacteria-biofilm interactions, which will be relevant to the fields of environmental, chemical, and biomedical engineering. The specific tasks include: 1) characterization of biofilms grown under environmentally relevant conditions in microfluidic cells; 2) probing bacterium-biofilm interactions using atomic force microscopy; 3) column filtration experiments including biofilms grown under environmentally relevant conditions; and 4) pore- and continuum-scale modeling of hydrodynamics and bacterial removal in engineered infiltration systems. Research findings will also be incorporated into undergraduate and graduate course materials and further augmented by the involvement of the PIs and their graduate students in organizing scientific activities for third through fifth-grade students in predominantly African American elementary/middle schools in inner-city Baltimore. Short courses on stormwater reuse-related topics will also be developed for the Nebraska EPSCoR's Young Nebraska Scientists summer camps which are attended by K-12 students, a large fraction of them to be underrepresented minorities.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Background

If not properly treated, stormwater carries pollutants that contaminate urban waterways. There is a critical need to improve the removal of contaminants from stormwater using low-cost, sustainable material within engineered infiltration systems. Urbanization has resulted in a significant increase in paved surfaces that prevent stormwater from being absorbed into soil through the natural water cycle.  Stormwater runoff can often pick up contaminants from paved surfaces, which eventually enter and pollute natural aquatic systems. Bacterial pathogens have been reported to be the most common contaminant that impairs stormwater for nonpotable reuse. Engineered infiltration systems, such as rain gardens or other green infrastructure projects, have been successful in many major cities as a best management practice for sustainable stormwater management. While engineered infiltration systems are cost-effective and sustainable, contaminant removal performance can vary substantially over time and between sites, making it difficult to predict and manage performance. To reduce the impact on the surrounding ecosystem of stormwater runoff, more work is needed to understand factors that affect the removal of pathogens in engineered infiltration systems.

          Bacterial biofilms growing within engineered infiltration systems are likely a key factor influencing pathogen removal performance in the field.  Since bacteria are ubiquitous in stormwater and form biofilms on almost any surface, bacterial biofilms will undoubtedly grow within engineered infiltration systems and influence the removal of pathogen contaminants. Research has been done to determine how stormwater chemistry and filtration system design impacts filter performance, but less work has focused on how biofilm characteristics impact pathogen removal. Previously, it was shown that laboratory strains of bacteria and genetically modified bacterial biofilms significantly change contaminant removal, yet it is unclear whether bacteria that would normally form biofilms within engineered infiltration systems could significantly alter performance. If natural biofilms can significantly change pathogen removal, what characteristics of the biofilms can explain the biggest differences in removal? We carried out both field and laboratory experiments to understand how biofilms affect pathogen removal within engineered infiltration systems.

Results

            Our results demonstrate that bacterial biofilms formed within engineered infiltration systems are diverse and different from the bacterial communities in stormwater. We found that the biofilm community composition within experimental engineered infiltration systems (i.e. sand columns) is relatively reproducible when formed under stable experimental conditions. We found that we could significantly change the removal of colloid (i.e. microplastics and pathogens) contaminants by growing biofilms of different strains of bacteria isolated from stormwater, regardless of the media type (sand or glass beads) or how well sterile media removed the colloids. Our results also explained what characteristics of these bacterial strains in stormwater explained most of the variation in removal. The adhesive energy (stickiness), measured with atomic force microscopy, between the biofilm and the colloids explain most, but not all, of the variability in removal performance between experimental columns containing different biofilms. We found that the biofilms with the highest removal and highest adhesive energy also had the longest polymers on the biofilm surface. These polymers likely shield the colloids from contact with the clean media surface and promote attachment to the biofilm surface. Finally, we found the pathogen removal efficiency of sand columns containing mixed community biofilms could be determined by the relative abundance of each strain and their unique removal efficiency.

Implications of our work  

          Our work demonstrates that understanding the diversity and dynamics of biofilms formed within engineered infiltration systems will be key to understanding pathogens and microplastics removal from these systems in the field. Researchers can use the results of our work to engineer better performing filters by encouraging growth of beneficial bacterial biofilms or adding bacteria with properties that promote contaminant removal. Our research suggests longer polymers on the biofilm surface strengthen the bond between biofilms and colloids and results in more colloid retention. However, beneficial bacteria will have to be one of the more abundant organisms within the biofilm community in order to have an impact on filter performance.

 

Broader Impacts

            This work has had many beneficial broader impacts on society. This award provided support for women and underrepresented minority students in science and engineering. It provided research opportunities for students involved in the Ingenuity Project at Baltimore Polytechnic Institute, a Baltimore City Public High School. Two students from the Ingenuity Project worked on this project and submitted their work to local and national science competitions, including one student who was named as a Regeneron Scholar semifinalist. This award supported outreach activities to teach science to 5th graders at City Springs Elementary School, a majority minority Baltimore City Public School.
